title: Musical Score Following using Statistical Inference
author: Josephine Cowley (Cambridge University), Professor Simon J. Godsill (Cambridge University)
relevance_why: The paper presents a novel approach using Gaussian Processes for real-time score following, which could influence Haohe Liu's work in audio processing and machine learning for music applications. The statistical inference techniques discussed could enhance tasks related to audio generation and transcription.
background: Mapping real-time performances to corresponding locations in a musical score to facilitate applications like automatic page turning and real-time accompaniment.
contribution: This report introduces a two-stage score follower using Gaussian Processes for music notation alignment, achieving successful real-time performance across various instruments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous score following methods often struggled with high accuracy during live performances due to performance errors and deviations from sheet music.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work leverages Gaussian Processes' flexibility and robustness, particularly through the use of Spectral Mixture kernels, to model and infer note sequences more effectively.

key_innovation: Utilizes a two-stage approach combining Gaussian Process inference with a Hidden Markov Model for enhanced real-time musical score alignment.
real_world_impact: The developed score follower system demonstrates significant practical applications in digital music technology, potentially improving the user experience for musicians using digital scores.
limitations: The main limitations are related to handling repeated notes and sustain pedal usage, as well as deviations from the score.

new_terms.Gaussian Processes: **Gaussian Processes** are a collection of random variables, any finite number of which have a joint Gaussian distribution, often used in regression tasks.
new_terms.Spectral Mixture Kernels: **Spectral Mixture Kernels** are a type of kernel function in Gaussian Processes that allow for complex covariance structures, particularly effective in modeling periodic and spectral data.

open_sourcing: The project has contributed a working score follower product that renders score positions in real-time using an adapted open-source user interface.
